description:
It seems that deceased or near death patients may be more virulent in passing on the disease than live ones.  The statistics have always seemed to show that burial rituals were vary contagious and now we have two nurses in PPE that have also come down with the disease.

  The Spanish nurse is confirmed to have assisted in cleaning up after the death of the priest.  No information othe than "multiple visits" has been given on the Dallas nurse so we don't know if she also was in the room after the patient was deceased.

Now to be fair, it may not be that the patient is actually anymore virilent but that caregivers are less vigilant.  After all the disease transmission has been linked to the same methods as AIDS.  However this virus is heavily present in sweat glands throughout the skin surface and tear ducts which many don't traditionally think of as "bodily" fluids.
summary: Have separate and distinct caretakers for living patients and deceased patients.
title: Separate Caretakers for the Living and the Dead
